description: From Middle English message, from Old French message, from Late Latin missaticum, from Latin mittere, missum (“to send”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *meyth₂- (“to exchange”). Displaced native Old English ærende which is survived in English errand.

entries.meaning: A communication, or what is communicated; any concept or information conveyed.
examples: I have a message from God unto thee.

entries.meaning: An underlying theme or conclusion to be drawn from something.
examples: The main message of the novel is that time heals all wounds.

entries.meaning: (UK, Ireland, chiefly in the plural) An errand.
(Ireland, Scotland, Northern England) See messages (“groceries, shopping”).

verbs.description: message (third-person singular simple present messages, present participle messaging, simple past and past participle messaged)

entries.meaning: To send a message to; to transmit a message to, e.g. as text via a cell phone.
examples: I messaged her about the concert.

entries.meaning: To send (something) as a message; usually refers to electronic messaging.
examples: She messaged me the information yesterday.
Please message the final report by fax.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To send a message or messages; to be capable of sending messages.
examples: We've implemented a new messaging service.
The runaway computer program was messaging non-stop.
